docs.title: Cooling Curve Simulation
docs.text: This script simulates a cooling process using a custom, non-physical model to demonstrate how different rate equations affect the cooling curve.

docs.title: The Model
docs.text:
This script uses a custom, non-linear differential equation:

\[ \frac{dT}{dt} = -k \sin(T) \]

This model is for illustrative purposes. It differs from the standard Newton's Law of Cooling, which describes physical cooling as:

\[ \frac{dT}{dt} = -k (T - T_{\text{ambient}}) \]

Newton's Law predicts an exponential decay, often with a plateau during phase changes. Our script's sine-based model results in an oscillating cooling rate, not dependent on ambient temperature difference.

docs.title: Curve Behavior
docs.text:
• Oscillating Cooling Rate: The sin(T) term causes the cooling rate (red dashed line) to oscillate, which is not physically realistic.
  • Wavy Temperature Decay: As a result, the temperature (blue line) decreases in a wave-like pattern, not an exponential decay.
  • No Phase-Change Plateau: The curve lacks a flat plateau, which would be present in a real-world cooling curve during solidification.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• T_initial: Starting temperature (°C).
  • T_ambient: Ambient temperature (°C) - Note: This parameter is not used in the current model.
  • k: Cooling rate constant.
  • dt: Time step for the simulation.
  • t_end: Total simulation time.

docs.title: Algorithm Pseudocode
docs.text:
Algorithm 1: Cooling Curve Simulation

Input:  T_initial = 100, k = 0.01, dt = 0.1, t_end = 100
Output: Temperature vs Time plot (cooling_curve.png)
Result: Simulated cooling curve using custom differential equation

 1  T ← T_initial
 2  t ← 0
 3  T_list ← []
 4  t_list ← []
 5  while t < t_end do
 6  │   dT ← -k · sin(T) · dt
 7  │   T ← T + dT
 8  │   if record_data then
 9  │   │   T_list.append(T)
10  │   │   t_list.append(t)
11  │   end
12  │   t ← t + dt
13  end
14  plot(t_list, T_list)
15  savefig("cooling_curve.png")

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: python3 CoolingCurve.py

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module contains electrochemical corrosion simulations including anodic mobility, Tafel kinetics, and reaction rate analyses for metal dissolution in aqueous environments.

docs.title: 1. Anodic Mobility
docs.text:
File: AnodicMobility/Mobility.py

Models the mobility of metal ions at the electrode-electrolyte interface:

\[ L_\alpha = L_0 \exp\left(\frac{\alpha_a n_M F \eta}{RT}\right) \]

where:

  • \(L_\alpha\) is the anodic mobility
  • \(L_0\) is the pre-exponential factor
  • \(\alpha_a\) is the anodic transfer coefficient
  • \(\eta = \phi_m - \phi_\ell\) is the overpotential
  • \(F\) is Faraday's constant
  • \(R\) is the gas constant
  • \(T\) is temperature

Parameters:

  • \(L_0 = 10^{-10}\) m⁴/(J·s)
  • \(\alpha_a = 0.5\)
  • \(n_M = 2\) (valence)
  • \(T = 298\) K

Output: Mobility.png, Overpotential.png

docs.title: 2. Tafel Kinetics
docs.text:
File: Tafel/Tafel.py

Simulates Butler-Volmer electrochemical kinetics for corrosion reactions:

\[ i_a = i_0 \exp\left(\frac{\alpha_a n F (E - E_{eq})}{RT}\right) \] \[ i_c = -i_0 \exp\left(\frac{-\alpha_c n F (E - E_{eq})}{RT}\right) \] \[ i_{net} = i_a + i_c \]

Parameters:

  • Exchange current density: \(i_0 = 1.0\) mA/cm²
  • Transfer coefficients: \(\alpha_a = \alpha_c = 0.5\)
  • Equilibrium potential: \(E_{eq} = 0.0\) V

Output: 4 plots showing Tafel behavior and effect of transfer coefficient

docs.title: 3. Reaction Kinetics (Time Evolution)
docs.text:
File: ReationTime/ReactionTime.py

Time-dependent simulation of metal corrosion reactions:

Reactions: 1. \(\text{M} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{MOH} + \text{H}^+\) with \(K_1 = 10^{-4}\) 2. \(\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{H}^+ + \text{OH}^-\) with \(K_2 = 10^{-14}\)

Rate equations:

\[ \frac{dx_M}{dt} = k_{b1}(-K_1 x_M + x_H x_{MOH}) \] \[ \frac{dx_H}{dt} = k_{b1}(K_1 x_M - x_H x_{MOH}) + k_{b2}(K_2 - x_H x_{OH}) \]

Parameters:

  • Backward rate constants: \(k_{b1} = 2.78 \times 10^3\), \(k_{b2} = 2.78 \times 10^3\)
  • Total concentration: \(C_{tot} = 5.55 \times 10^4\) mol/m³
  • Time step: \(\Delta t = 10^{-5}\) s
  • Total steps: \(2 \times 10^5\)

Output: ReactionTime_Evolution_Rates.png, ReactionTime_Evolution_Concentrations.png

docs.title: 4. Reaction Kinetics (Steady State)
docs.text:
File: ReactionNew/ReactionNew.py

Steady-state analysis of corrosion reactions as a function of metal concentration:

Features:

  • pH calculation as a function of metal mole fraction
  • Reaction rate profiles for Fe, FeOH, H⁺, and OH⁻
  • Logarithmic pH plots

Output: 5 plots including Metal_Oxide.png, Hydrogen_Oxide.png, PH_vs_xM.png, PH.png, log_PH.png

docs.title: 5. Cui Model
docs.text:
File: Cui.py

Simple concentration normalization for solid and saturated states:

\[ C_{Se} = \frac{C_{solid}}{C_{solid}} = 1 \] \[ C_{Le} = \frac{C_{sat}}{C_{solid}} = 0.0357 \]

Parameters:

  • \(C_{solid} = 143\) mol/m³ (atomic density)
  • \(C_{sat} = 5.1\) mol/m³ (solubility limit)

docs.title: Theory
docs.text:
The simulations are based on fundamental electrochemical principles:

Butler-Volmer Equation:

\[ i = i_0 \left[\exp\left(\frac{\alpha_a nF\eta}{RT}\right) - \exp\left(\frac{-\alpha_c nF\eta}{RT}\right)\right] \]

Nernst Equation:

\[ E = E^0 + \frac{RT}{nF}\ln\frac{[Ox]}{[Red]} \]

Mass Action Law:

\[ K_{eq} = \frac{[products]}{[reactants]} \]

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Run individual simulations
cd AnodicMobility && python3 Mobility.py
cd Tafel && python3 Tafel.py
cd ReationTime && python3 ReactionTime.py
cd ReactionNew && python3 ReactionNew.py
python3 Cui.py

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Predicting corrosion rates in aqueous environments
  • Electrode kinetics analysis
  • pH evolution during metal dissolution
  • Electrochemical cell design
  • Passivation and protection studies
  • Corrosion inhibitor screening

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Cui, F., et al. (2022) - Mole fraction formulation for corrosion
  • Butler-Volmer kinetics - Classical electrochemistry
  • Tafel extrapolation methods

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module contains simulations related to fracture mechanics, including energy release rates and hydrogen-induced fracture degradation.

docs.title: Energy Release Rate
docs.text:
Located in Energy/EnergyReleaseRate.py

Demonstrates Griffith's theory of crack propagation under:

  • Fixed load (stress-controlled): \(G = \frac{\sigma^2 \pi a}{E}\)
  • Fixed displacement (strain-controlled): \(G = \frac{\delta^2 E \pi}{a}\)

Parameters:

  • Young's modulus: \(E = 210\) GPa
  • Applied stress: \(\sigma = 100\) MPa
  • Critical energy: \(G_c = 1000\) J/m²

Output: EnergyReleaseRate.png

docs.title: Hydrogen-Induced Degradation
docs.text:
Located in Hydrogen/Hydrogen.py

Models the reduction of fracture energy due to hydrogen embrittlement using the Langmuir–McLean isotherm:

\[ \theta = \frac{C}{C + \exp(-\Delta G_{gb} / RT)} \] \[ \frac{G_c(C)}{G_c(0)} = 1 - \chi \theta \]

Parameters:

  • Temperature: \(T = 300\) K
  • Grain boundary energy: \(\Delta G_{gb} = 30\) kJ/mol
  • Degradation factor: \(\chi = 0.41\)

Output: Hydrogen_FractureEnergy_vs_Concentration.png

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
cd Energy && python3 EnergyReleaseRate.py
cd Hydrogen && python3 Hydrogen.py

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Predicting crack propagation in brittle materials
  • Understanding hydrogen embrittlement
  • Materials design for fracture resistance

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module visualizes 2D gradient fields and 3D surface plots for understanding spatial derivatives and field distributions.

docs.title: 1. 2D Gradient Field
docs.text:
Visualizes the temperature field:

\[ T(x,y) = e^{-0.1(x^2 + y^2)} \]

with gradient vectors \((\nabla T)\) overlaid as arrows.

docs.title: 2. 3D Surface Plot
docs.text:
Creates a smooth 3D surface using:

\[ z(x,y) = \frac{\sin(r)}{r + \epsilon} \]

where \(r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}\)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• gradient_plot.png - 2D contour plot with gradient arrows
  • Surf.png - 3D surface plot

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: python3 Gradient.py

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Understanding heat flow and diffusion
  • Visualizing potential energy landscapes
  • Demonstrating field gradients in physics

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module contains phase-field simulations for microstructure evolution, including basic interface energy calculations and parabolic diffusion-controlled phase transformations.

docs.title: 1. Basic Phase-Field
docs.text:
File: Basic/Basic.py

Demonstrates fundamental phase-field concepts including interface energy and width calculations.

Theory:

The phase-field variable \(\phi\) varies smoothly across interfaces:

\[ \phi(x) = rac{1}{2}\left(1 + anh\left( rac{x}{\xi} ight) ight) \]

where \(\xi\) is the interface width.

Free Energy Functional:

\[ F = \int \left[f_{bulk}(\phi) + f_{grad}( abla\phi) ight] dx \]

Bulk Free Energy (Double-Well Potential):

\[ f_{bulk} = W \phi^2 (1 - \phi)^2 \]

Gradient Energy:

\[ f_{grad} = rac{1}{2}\kappa | abla\phi|^2 \]

Physical Interpretation:

For physically meaningful interface energy \(\sigma\) and width \(\eta\):

\[ f_{bulk} = rac{18\sigma}{\eta} \phi^2 (1 - \phi)^2 \] \[ f_{grad} = rac{1}{2}\sigma\eta | abla\phi|^2 \]

Parameters:

  • \(W = 1\) - Energy barrier
  • \(\kappa = 0.5\) - Gradient coefficient
  • Domain: \(L = 20\)
  • Grid points: \(N_x = 500\)

Output: 3 plots

  • Emperical_phi.png - Phase-field profile
  • Emperical_potential.png - Bulk energy density
  • Emperical_grad.png - Gradient energy density

docs.title: 2. Parabolic Diffusion with Phase Transformation
docs.text:
File: ParabolicDiffusion/ParabolicDiffusion.py

Simulates coupled diffusion and phase transformation with parabolic free energy.

Governing Equations:

Diffusion Equation (with chemical potential):

\[ rac{\partial c}{\partial t} = abla \cdot \left[M abla \mu ight] \]

Chemical Potential:

\[ \mu = rac{\partial f}{\partial c} = A V_m (c - C_{eq}^\alpha)\phi_\alpha + A V_m (c - C_{eq}^ eta)\phi_ eta \]

Phase-Field Evolution (Allen-Cahn):

\[ rac{\partial \phi}{\partial t} = L_\phi \left[\sigma( abla^2\phi - rac{\partial W}{\partial \phi}) + rac{6}{w}\phi_\alpha\phi_ eta\Delta f ight] \]

Double-Well Potential Derivative:

\[ rac{\partial W}{\partial \phi} = rac{72 \cdot 2}{w^2} \phi(1-\phi)(1-2\phi) \]

Free Energy Densities:

  • Phase \(\alpha\): \(f_\alpha = rac{1}{2}A(c - C_{eq}^\alpha)^2\)
  • Phase \( eta\): \(f_ eta = rac{1}{2}A(c - C_{eq}^ eta)^2\)

Driving Force:

\[ \Delta f = (f_ eta - f_\alpha)\phi_\alpha\phi_ eta \]

Parameters:

  • Grid spacing: \(dx = 0.5\) nm
  • Grid points: \(N_x = 100\)
  • Time step: \(dt = 10^{-4}\) s
  • Total steps: 10,000
  • Interface width: \(w = 8\,dx = 4\) nm
  • Free energy parameter: \(A = 4 imes 10^8\) J/m³
  • Phase-field mobility: \(L_\phi = 10^{-15}\) m³/(J·s)
  • Surface tension: \(\sigma = 0.5\) J/m²
  • Diffusion coefficients: \(D_\alpha = D_ eta = 5 imes 10^{-16}\) m²/s
  • Equilibrium concentrations:
  • \(C_{eq}^\alpha = 1.0\)
  • \(C_{eq}^ eta = 0.2\)

Stability Criteria:

The simulation checks the CFL (Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy) condition:

\[ rac{\dot{c} \cdot \Delta t}{c} < 0.1 \] \[ D \cdot \Delta t < rac{\Delta x^2}{6} \]

Output: 2 plots

  • DrivingForce.png - Driving force evolution
  • Composition_Energy.png - Final composition profile and energy evolution

docs.title: Phase-Field Method
docs.text:
The phase-field method replaces sharp interfaces with diffuse interfaces described by a continuous order parameter \(\phi\):

  • \(\phi = 0\): Phase \(\beta\) (e.g., liquid)
  • \(\phi = 1\): Phase \(\alpha\) (e.g., solid)
  • \(0 < \phi < 1\): Interface region

docs.title: Interface Properties
docs.text:
Interface Energy:

\[ \sigma = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[f_{bulk}(\phi) + f_{grad}\right] dx \]

Interface Width:

\[ \xi \approx \frac{\text{distance where } \phi \text{ varies from 0.1 to 0.9}}{\text{characteristic length}} \]

docs.title: Thermodynamic Consistency
docs.text:
The model satisfies:

  1. Energy minimization: System evolves to minimize free energy
  2. Mass conservation: Total concentration is conserved
  3. Second law: Entropy production is always non-negative

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Run Basic simulation
cd Basic && python3 Basic.py

# Run Parabolic Diffusion simulation
cd ParabolicDiffusion && python3 ParabolicDiffusion.py

docs.title: Basic Simulation
docs.text:
• Shows interface width \(\xi \approx 2.2\)
  • Total interface energy \(F \approx 1.0\) (physical units)
  • Demonstrates balance between bulk and gradient energies

docs.title: Parabolic Diffusion Simulation
docs.text:
• Tracks phase transformation kinetics
  • Monitors driving force evolution
  • Validates mass conservation (error < 0.15%)
  • Shows energy decrease over time (thermodynamic consistency)

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Solidification: Dendritic growth, eutectic structures
  • Precipitation: Second-phase nucleation and growth
  • Grain growth: Polycrystalline evolution
  • Spinodal decomposition: Phase separation
  • Recrystallization: Microstructure refinement
  • Additive manufacturing: Rapid solidification modeling

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Allen, S. M., & Cahn, J. W. (1979). A microscopic theory for antiphase boundary motion
  • Steinbach, I. (2009). Phase-field models in materials science
  • Chen, L.-Q. (2002). Phase-field models for microstructure evolution
  • Provatas, N., & Elder, K. (2010). Phase-field methods in materials science

docs.title: Numerical Methods
docs.text:
• Finite difference for spatial derivatives
  • Forward Euler for time integration
  • Periodic boundary conditions for concentration
  • CFL condition checking for stability
  • Mass conservation monitoring

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module simulates field evolution under various potential energy landscapes, including diffusion-advection, potential field evolution, and spring chain dynamics.

docs.title: 1. Advection (Potential-Driven Diffusion)
docs.text:
File: Advection/advection.py

Simulates coupled diffusion and advection under a parabolic potential:

\[ rac{\partial f}{\partial t} = D abla^2 f + abla \cdot (f abla V) \]
  • Potential: \(V(x) = 0.5(x - 5)^2\)
  • Diffusion coefficient: \(D = 0.1\)
  • Output: diffusion_advection.png

docs.title: 2. Potential Field Evolution
docs.text:
File: Potential/Potential.py

Models field decay under a quartic potential:

\[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial t} = -V(x) \cdot f \]
  • Potential: \(V(x) = 0.5(x - 5)^4\)
  • Output: V_f.png, f_evolution_snapshots.png

docs.title: 3. Spring Chain Dynamics
docs.text:
File: Spring/spring_file.py

Simulates a 1D spring chain with external potential using:

\[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial t} = M \left( k \nabla^2 f - 2V(x)f \right) \]
  • Spring constant: \(k = 1\)
  • Mobility: \(M = 1\)
  • Potential: \(V(x) = 0.5(x - 5)^4\)
  • Output: spring_chain_snapshots.png

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
cd Advection && python3 advection.py
cd Potential && python3 Potential.py
cd Spring && python3 spring_file.py

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Phase field modeling
  • Pattern formation
  • Reaction-diffusion systems
  • Energy landscape exploration

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This module contains advanced simulations of electrochemical charge transport, Poisson equation solvers, and coupled diffusion-migration systems.

docs.title: 1. Charge Transport
docs.text:
File: ChargeTransport/ChargeTransport.py

Solves the 1D Poisson equation using the Successive Over-Relaxation (SOR) method:

\[ \frac{d^2\phi}{dx^2} = -\frac{\rho(x)}{\epsilon_0} \]
  • Method: SOR with \(\omega = 1.9\)
  • Output: Numerical_SOR.png

docs.title: 2. Diffusion
docs.text:
File: Diffusion/Diffusion.py

Pure diffusion simulation using FFT-based spectral methods:

\[ \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} = D \nabla^2 \rho \]
  • Diffusion coefficient: \(D = 10^{-4}\) m²/s
  • Output: Diffusion_and_Laplacian.png

docs.title: 3. Mole Fraction Poisson Solve
docs.text:
File: MoleFractionPoissonSolve/MoleFractionPoissonSolve.py

Simulates ionic transport in corrosion using Cui et al. (2022) parameters:

  • Fe²⁺ and Cl⁻ ions
  • Coupled Poisson-Nernst-Planck system
  • Output: ElectricField_Vectors.png, Density.png

docs.title: 4. Poisson Equation (1D)
docs.text:
File: PoissonEquation/PoissonEquation.py

Comprehensive 1D Poisson solver with:

  • FFT-based solution
  • Electric field calculation
  • Charge flux analysis
  • Output: Multiple analysis plots

docs.title: 5. Poisson Equation (2D)
docs.text:
File: PoissonEquation2D/PoissonEquation2D.py

2D Poisson equation solver with vector field visualization:

\[ \nabla^2 \phi = -\frac{\rho}{\epsilon_0} \]
  • Separates positive/negative charges
  • Computes electric field vectors
  • Output: 6 field plots with vector arrows

docs.title: 6. Poisson Equation with Time Evolution
docs.text:
File: PoissonEquationTime/PoissonEquationTime.py

Time-dependent Poisson-Nernst-Planck system:

\[ \frac{\partial c_i}{\partial t} = -\nabla \cdot \mathbf{J}_i \] \[ \mathbf{J}_i = -D \nabla c_i + z_i \mu c_i \mathbf{E} \]
  • Drift-diffusion coupling
  • Fe²⁺ and Cl⁻ migration
  • Output: Charge_Evolution.png, Density_M_High.txt

docs.title: Theory
docs.text:
These simulations solve the fundamental equations of electrochemistry:

Poisson Equation:

\[ abla^2 \phi = - rac{ ho}{\epsilon_0} \]

Nernst-Planck Equation:

\[ \mathbf{J}_i = -D_i abla c_i + z_i rac{F}{RT} D_i c_i abla \phi \]

Continuity Equation:

\[ rac{\partial c_i}{\partial t} + abla \cdot \mathbf{J}_i = 0 \]

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
cd ChargeTransport && python3 ChargeTransport.py
cd Diffusion && python3 Diffusion.py
cd MoleFractionPoissonSolve && python3 MoleFractionPoissonSolve.py
cd PoissonEquation && python3 PoissonEquation.py
cd PoissonEquation2D && python3 PoissonEquation2D.py
cd PoissonEquationTime && python3 PoissonEquationTime.py

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Corrosion modeling
  • Battery simulation
  • Electrochemical deposition
  • Semiconductor device physics
  • Biological ion channels
